THE TWENTY—FOUR INCH GAUGE is an m - etrument made use of by operative Masons to measure and lay out their work. But we, as free and accepted Masons, are taught to make use of it for the more noble and glorious purpose of divid - ing our time. It being divided into twenty-four equal parts is emblematical of the twenty-four hours of the day, which we are taught to divide into three parts, whereby we find a part for the service of God and a distressed worthy brother; a part for our usual avocations; and a part for refresh - ment and sleep. 19.
